title: Before 27 December 2017, will Brazil's Chamber of Deputies vote to send Brazil's President Michel Temer to a Supreme Court or Senate trial?
preds: Groupthink will make a senate trial or any judge call impossible
Know little about this but the news has gone quiet it seems.
The government has started to negotiate an amendment to extend those rights to former presidents.

He is extremely unpopular. I expect all the parties of the left and center, and even some on the center-right, would join forces to try him. The Left, in particular, would love to do this as revenge for the impeachment of Dilma and the charges against Lula.
Had angioplasty in recent days. Trial was blocked. No new movement. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/25/world/americas/brazil-michel-temer-corruption.html

It seems exceedingly unlikely to occur, but you never want to underestimate Brazil. With the holiday approaching, most people are likely to focus more on their personal lives. However, were an alarming new accusation or development to occur (always possible in Brazilian politics!), it could also mean people are more free to hit the streets in mass again and instigate an trial.

The lower house of Brazil's Congress, which has the authority to decide whether a president should stand trial by the Supreme Court, voted 251-233 to throw out charges of obstruction of justice and organized crime filed by federal prosecutors.
Need 2/3 majority, and closing in on Christmas with no public demonstrations. This is extremely unlikely
The evidences against the President are not well-founded. As a consequence, there are no mass demonstrations against him.
Christmas very close nothing moves. No desire to rock the country now.

Hedging. Still not literally impossible? So not 0. Though less than two months to take action, and with likely dwindling interest in the political fallout, excepting the potential of something catastrophic.
the impeachment push seems to be running out of steam

Lower House blocked corruption trial on Oct 25th. Given the recent instability with Dilma and the rampant corruption the opposition might settle for change in the 2018 election. His popularity very low.

The lower house of Congress voted 251-233 on Wednesday to shelve the corruption case against Temer, ensuring his survival in office
https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2017-10-26/split-in-temer-ruling-coalition-likely-dooms-reform-agenda
Establishing baseline forecast, will update based on further information and analysis.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Its seems that the Chamber of Deputies was a long way short of the two thirds vote
IMHO, the fat lady just sang. http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-41755666
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

The Senate will remain supportive of Temer, denying his opponents the 2/3 vote needed to authorize a trial. The economy is picking up, Temer is a caretaker, so there's no need to for ambitious allies to jump ship and go after him at this point.
Maybe next year when it's closer to the next Presidential election.
More time will be needed if the Chamber wishes to take this course of action.
Brazilian deputies may want to send the president to court but corruption is always a gradual process and sending the president to court may need more time.
I like @patrickmeehan5's comment "He'll achieve lame duck status instead," and a supporting news link at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/595754.
He'll achieve lame duck status instead. https://www.gisreportsonline.com/brazils-embattled-president-is-still-not-in-the-clear,expert-view,2308.html
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

This news story reported to HFC by @shivadiva at https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-corruption-temer/brazil-congressional-report-recommends-shelving-temer-charges-idUSKBN1CF2W4 slams the door on a yes answer.

Unlikely. The August vote had 263 out of 517 vote against sending him to trial.115 votes will have to swing from the against and abstainers to achieve the two-thirds  vote required. There are fresh charges and discontent with the pension reforms he is pushing through. He is 75 and his term is due to finish 1st Jan 2019 so as next year progresses he could be perceived as expendable by political colleagues. I feel the timing of any successful vote is more likely next year than this year.

They already tried and failed, personally I think Temer survives the next attempt even if only because he knows were all the bodies are buried but more broadly because I don't see what has changed in the political situation.

Second accusation by the PGR flawed by collusion between prosecutors and the Batista brothers.  The limited time remaining before the next presidential election precludes another attempt at impeachment.

One never knows for certain, but:
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-politics-corruption/brazil-supreme-court-allows-congress-last-word-on-removal-of-lawmakers-idUSKBN1CH02N
See paragraph 4.
Because Bonifacio de Andrada recently recommended the charges be shelved he will likely not face charges during this timeframe
